sourceDesc:
<<<<<<< HEAD
The preacher, or the art and method of preaching: shewing the most ample directions and rules for invention, method, expression, and books whereby a minister may be furnished with such helps as may make him a useful laborer in the Lords vineyard. / By William Chappell Bishop of Cork, sometime Fellow of Christs College in Cambridge. Methodus concionandi. English Chappell, William, 1582-1649. Brough, W. (William), d. 1671.
[12], 204, [12] p.
Printed for Edw. Farnham, and are to be sold at his shop in Popes-head Palace neer Corn-hill, London, : 1656.
A translation of: Methodus concionandi. Editor's preface signed: Phil. Christianus, i.e. William Brough. The last six leaves bear "A nomenclator of sundry tracts, sermons, and commentaries ...". Annotations on Thomason copy: "March 24"; "March". Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
=======

Methodus concionandi. English Chappell, William, 1582-1649. Brough, W. (William), d. 1671.
[12], 204, [12] p.
Printed for Edw. Farnham, and are to be sold at his shop in Popes-head Palace neer Corn-hill, London, : 1656.
A translation of: Methodus concionandi. Editor's preface signed: Phil. Christianus, i.e. William Brough. The last six leaves bear "A nomenclator of sundry tracts, sermons, and commentaries ...". Annotations on Thomason copy: "March 24"; "March". Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
Edw. Farnham
his shop in Popes-head Palace neer Corn-hill
